Heere bigynneth the Shipman his tale.
A Marchant whilom dwelled at seint denys
Þᵗat riche was for which men helde hym wys
A wif he hadde of excellent beautee
And compaignable ⁊and reuelous was she
Which is a þyng þᵗat causeth moore dispence
Than worth is al þe chiere and reuerence
Þᵗat men hem doon at feestes ⁊and at daunces
Swiche salutacioıı̄uns ⁊and contenaunces
Passen as dooth a shadwe vp on the wal
But wo is hym þᵗat payen moot for al
Þe seely housbonde algates he moot paye
He moot vs boþe clothe / ⁊and he moot vs arraye
For his owene worship re richely
In which array we dauncen Iolily
And if þᵗat he noght paye ꝑper/parauenture
Or ellis r list noght swich despense endure
But þynkeþ it is wasted and I lost
Thanne moot another payen for owre Cost
Or lene vs gold ⁊and þat is ꝑper/parilous
This noble Marchaut heeld a worthy hous
For which he hadde alday so greet repair
For his largesse / ⁊and for his wif was fair
That wonder is but herkeneþ to my tale
Among alle thise geestes greete ⁊and smale
Ther was a Monk a fayr man ⁊and a bold
I trowe a thritty wynter he was oold
That eủer/ree in oon was drawynge to þᵗat place
This yonge Monk þᵗat was so fair of face
Aqueynted so was wᵗith the good man
Sith þᵗat hire firste knowleche bigan
Þᵗat in his hous as famulier was he
As it is possyble any freend to be
And for as muchel as this goode man
And eek þis Monk of which þᵗat I began
Wer̉er/re bothe two born in o village
The Monk hym claymeth as for Cosynage
And he agayn he seith nat ones nay
But was as glad ther of as fowl of day
For to his herte it was a greet plesaunce
Thus been they knyt wᵗith eterne allyaunce
⁊and ech of hem gan oother for tassure
Of bretherede whil þᵗat hir lyf may dure
Free was daun Iohn ⁊and namely of dispense
As in þᵗat hous ⁊and ful of diligence
To doon plesaunce ⁊and also greet costage
He nat forgat to gyue the leeste page
Whan þᵗat he cam som manere honeste þyng
For which þey were as glad of his comyng
As fowel is fayn whan þᵗat þe sonne vpriseth
Namoore of this a now for it suffiseth
But so bifel þᵗat Marchant on a day
Shoop hym to make reedy his array
Toward the toun of Brugges for to fare
To byen ther a porcioıı̄un of ware
For which he haþ to Parys sent anoon
A messager and pyed hath daun Iohn
Þᵗat he sholde come to seint denys ⁊and pleye
Wᵗith hym ⁊and wᵗith his wif a day or tweye
Er he to Brugges wente in alle wyse
This noble Monk of whiche I yow deuyse
Hath of his Abbot / as hym list licence
By cause he was a man of high prudence
And eek an Officer out for to ryde
To seen hire granges ⁊and hire bernes wyde
And vn to seint Denys he comth anon .
Who was so welcome as my lord daun Iohn
Owr deere Cosyn ful of curteisye
Wᵗith hym he broghte a Iubbe of Maluesye
And eek a nother ful of fyn vernage
And volatyl as ay was his vsage
And thus I lete hem ete ⁊and drynke ⁊and pleye
This Marchaunt and þis Monk a day or tweye
¶ The thridde day þis Marchant vp ariseth
And on hise nedes sadly hym auyseth
And vp in to his Countoᵘur hous goth he
To rekne wᵗith hym self weel may be
Of thilke yeer how þᵗat it wᵗith hym stood
And how þᵗat he despended hadde his good
And if þᵗat he encressed were or noon
Hise bookes ⁊and hise bagges many oon
He leith bi forn hym on his countyngbord
Ful riche was his tresor ⁊and his hoord
For which ful faste his Countoᵘur doore he shette
And eek he nolde þᵗat no man shulde hym lette
Of his acountes for þe meene tyme
And þus he sit til it was passed pryme
¶ Daun Iohn was risen in þe morwe also
⁊and in þe gardyn walkeþ too ⁊and froo
And hath hise þynges seyd ful curteisly
Þis goode wif cam walkynge pⁱriuely
In to þe gardyn ther he walketh softe
And hym salueth as she hath doon ofte
A mayde child cam in hire compaignye
Which as hire list she may goủer/rene ⁊and gye
For yet vnder the yerde was the mayde
¶ O deer Cosyn myn daun Iohn she sayde
What eileth yow so rathe for to ryse
Neece quod he it oght ynogh suffyse
Fyue houres for to sleepe vp on a nyght
But it were for an old appalled wight
As been thise wedded men þᵗat lye ⁊and dare
As in a forme sit a wery hare
Were al forstraught wᵗith houndes grete ⁊and smale
But deer Neece why be ye so pale
I trowe certes þᵗat owre goode man
Hath yow laboured sith the nyght bigan
Þᵗat yow were neede to resten hastily
And wᵗith þᵗat word he lowgh ful myryly
And of his owne thoght he wex al red
This faire wyf gan forto shake hire heed
And seyde þus ye god woot al quod she
Nay Cosyn myn it stant nat soo wᵗith me
For by þᵗat god þᵗat yaf me soule and lyf
In al the Reawme of Fraunce is þer no wyf
That lasse lust haþ to þᵗat sory play
For I may synge Allas and weylaway
That I was born but to no wight quod she
Dar I nat telle how þᵗat it stant wᵗith me
Wherfore I thynke out of þis land to wende
Or elles of my self to make an eende
So ful am I of drede and of care
¶ This Monk bigan vp on this wyf to stare
And seyde Allas my Neece god forbede
That ye for any sorwe or any dreede
For do youre self / but telleþ me youre greef
ꝐPer/Parauenture I may in youre meschief
Conseille or helpe ⁊and þerfore telleþ me
Al youre anoy for it shal been secree
For on my porthos I make an ooth
That neủer/ree in my lyf for lief or looth
Ne shal I of no conseil you bywreye
The same ageyn to yow quod she I seye
By god ⁊and by þis Porthos I yow swere
Thogh men me wolde al into peces tere
Ne shal I neủer/ree forto gon to helle
Biwreye a word of thynge þᵗat ye me telle
Noght for no Cosynage ne alliaunce
But v̉er/reraily for loue and affiaunce
Thus been they sworn ⁊and heer vp on they keste
And ech of hem toold other what hem leste
¶ Cosyn quod she if þᵗat I hadde a space
As I haue noon and namely in this place
Thanne wolde I telle a legende of my lyf
What I haue suffred sith I was a wyf
Wᵗith myn housbonde al be he youre Cosyn
¶ Nay quod this Monk by god ⁊and seint Martyn
He nys namoore Cosyn vn to me
Than is þe leef þat hangeth on the tree
I clepe hym so by seint Denys of Fraunce
To han þe moore cause of Acqueyntaunce
Of yow which I haue loued specially
Abouen alle women sikerly
This swere I yow on my ꝓprofessyoıı̄un
Telleth youre grief lest þᵗat he come a doıı̄un
And hasteþ yow and gooth awey anon
My deer loue quod she o my Daun Iohn
Ful lief were me this conseil for to hyde
But owt it moot I may namoore abyde
Myn housbonde is to me þe worste man
That eủer/ree was sith þᵗat the world bigan
But sith I am a wyf it sit nat me
To telle no wight of owre pⁱriuetee
Neither a bedde ne in noon other place
God shilde I sholde it tellen for his grace
A wyf ne shal nat seyn of hire housbonde
But al honoᵘur as I kan vnderstonde
Saue vn to yow thus muche I tellen shal
As help me god / he is noght worth at al
In no degre the value of a Flye
But yet me greueth most his nygardye
And weel ye woot þᵗat wōmmen naturelly
Desiryn thynges sixe as weel as . I .
They wolde þat hire housbondes sholde bee
Hardy and wyse ⁊and ryche and þer to free
And buxom vn to his wyf ⁊and fressh a bedde
But by þᵗat ilke lord þᵗat for vs bledde
For his honoᵘur my self for to arraye
A sonday next I moot needes paye
An hundred frankes or elles am I lorn
Yet wer me leủer/ree þᵗat I were onborn
Than me wer doon a sclaundr or vileynye
And if myn housbonde eek myghte it espye
I nere but lost and þerfore I yow preye
Lene me þis sōmme or elles moot I deye
Daun Iohn I seye lene me thise hundred frankes
ꝐPer/Pardee I wol noght fayle you my thankes
If þᵗat yow list to doon þᵗat I yow praye
For at a c̉er/reteyn day I wol yow paye
And doon to yow what plesance ⁊and seruyse
That I may doon ryght as yow list deuyse
And but I do god take on me vengeance
As foul as eủer/ree hadde Genylou of Fraıı̄unce
¶ This gentil Monk answerede in þis maneere
Now trewely myn owne lady deere
I haue quod he on yow so greet a routhe
That I yow swere ⁊and plighte you my trouthe
Þat whan your housbonde is to Flaundres fare
I wol delyuere yow out of þis care
For I wol brynge yow an hundred Frankes
And wᵗith þᵗat word he caughte hire by the flankes
And hire embraceth harde ⁊and kiste hire ofte
Gooth now youre weye quod he al stille ⁊and softe
And lat vs dyne as soone as þᵗat ye may
For by my Chilyndre it is pryme of day
Gooth now ⁊and beeth as trewe as I shal be
¶ Now elles god forbeede sire quod she
And forth she gooth as Ioly as a pye
And bad the Cookes þᵗat they shulde hem hye
So þᵗat men myghte dyne and þᵗat anoon
Vp to hire housbonde is this wyf ygoon
And knokketh at his Countoᵘur boldely
Who ther quode he Peter it am I
Quod she what sire how longe wol ye faste
How longe tyme wol ye rekne ⁊and caste
Youre sōmmes ⁊and youre bookes ⁊and youre thynges
The deuel haue part on alle swiche rekenynges
Ye haue ynogh ꝑper/pardee of goddes sonde
Come doun to day ⁊and lat youre bagges stonde
Ne be ye nat a shamed þᵗat daun Iohn
Shal fastynge al this day alenge goon
What lat vs heere a masse ⁊and go we dyne
¶ Wyf quod this man litel kanstow deuyne
The curious bisynesse . þat we haue
For of vs Chapmen also god me saue
And by þᵗat lord that cleped is seint Yue
Skarsly amonges twelue ten shul thryue
Continuelly lastyng vn to owre age
We may weel make chiere ⁊and good visage
⁊and dryue forth þe world as it may be
⁊and kepen oure estaat in pryuytee
Til we be dede or ell þᵗat we pleye
A pilgrymage or goon out of þe weye
And þerfore haue I greet necessytee
Vpon þys queynte world tauyse me
For eủer/ree mo we moote stonde in drede
Of hap ⁊and Fortune in owre chapmanhede
To Flaundres wol I go to morwe at day
And come Agayn as soone as eủer/re I may
For which my deere wif I the biseeke
As be to euery wight buxom ⁊and meeke
And for to keepe oure good be curious
And honestely gouerne weel owre hous
Þᵘ hast ynogh in euery maner wyse
That to a thrifty houshold may suffise
The lakketh noon array ne noon vitaille
Of siluer in thy purs shaltow nat faille
And wᵗith þᵗat word his Countoᵘur doore he shette
⁊and doun he gooth no lengere wolde he lette
And hastily a masse was there seyd
⁊and spedily the tablees were I leyd
And to þe dyner faste they hem spedde
And richely þis Monk the Chapman fedde
At after dyner daun Iohn sobrely
This chapman took a part ⁊and pⁱriuely
He seyde hym thus Cosyn it standeþ so
Þᵗat weel I see to Brugges wol ye go
God ⁊and Seint Augustyn speede you ⁊and gyde
I preye you cosyn wisely þᵗat ye ryde
Goủer/reneþ yow also of youre diete
Attemprely ⁊and namely in þis heete
Bitwixe vs two nedeth no strange fare
Farewel Cosyn god shilde yow fro care
And if þᵗat any by day / or nyght
If it lye in my power ⁊and my myght
That ye me wole comaunde in any wyse
It shal be doon / right as ye wole deuyse
O thyng er þᵗat ye goon if it may be
I wolde preye yow forto lene me
An hundred frankes for a wyke or tweye
For certein beestes . þat I moste beye
To stoore wᵗith a place þᵗat is oures
God helpe me so I wolde it were youres
I shal nat fayle seurely of my day
Nat for a thousand Frankes a Mile way
But lat this þyng be secree I yow preye
For yet to nyght thise beestes moot I beye
And fare now weel myn owne Cosyn deere
Graunt mcy of youre cost ⁊and of youre chiere
This noble Marchant gentilly anon
Answerde ⁊and seyde o Cosyn myn Daun Iohn
Now sikerly þis is a smal requeeste
My gold is youres whan þᵗat it yow leste
And nat oonly my gold but my chaffare
Taak what you list god shilde þᵗat ye spare
But o thyng is ye knowe it wel ynogh
Of Chapmen þᵗat hir moneye is hire plogh
We may creance whil we han a name
But goldlees for to been it is a shame
Paye it agayn whan it lith in your eese
After my myght ful fayn I wol you pleese
Thise hundred frankes / he fette forth anon
And pⁱriuely he took hem to daun Iohn
No wight in al þis world wiste of þis loone
Sauynge þis Marchant ⁊and daun Iohn Allone
They drynke ⁊and speke ⁊and rome a while ⁊and pleye
Til þᵗat daun Iohn rideth to his Abbeye
¶ The morwe cam ⁊and foorth þis Marchant rydeth
To Flaundres ward his prentys weel hym gideth
Til he cam in to Brugges myrily
Now goth þis Marchant faste ⁊and bisyly
Aboute his neede byeth and creaunceth
He neyther pleyeth at dees / ne daunceth
But as a Marchant shortely for to telle
He lat his lyf ⁊and ther I lete hym dwelle
¶ The sonday next this Marchaunt was agoon
To seint Denys ycomen is daun Iohn
Wᵗith crowne ⁊and berd al fressh ⁊and newe y shaue
In al þe hous ther nas so litel a knaue
Ne no wight elles þᵗat he nas ful fayn
That my lord daun Iohn was come agayn
And shortely to the poynt right for to gon
This faire wyf accorded wᵗith daun Iohn
That for hise hundred frankes he sholde al nyght
Haue hire in hise Armes bolt vp right
And this accord / ꝑper/parfourned was in deede
In myrthe al nyght a bisy lyf þey leede
Til it was day þᵗat daun Iohn wente his way
⁊and bad þe meyne fareweel haue good day
For noon of hem ne no wight in þe town
Hath of daun Iohn right no suspecioun
And foorth he rideth hoom to his Abbeye
Or where hym list namoore of hym I seye
¶ This Marchant whan þᵗat ended was þe Faire
To seint Denys he gan forto repaire
And wᵗith his wyf he makeþ feeste ⁊and cheere
And telleþ hir þat chaffare is so deere
Þat nedes moste he make a cheuyssance
For he was bounden in a Reconyssance
To payen twenti thousand sheeld anoon
For which this Marchant is to Parys goon
To borwe of certein frendes þᵗat he hadde
A certeyn Frankes ⁊and sōmme wᵗith hym he ladde
And whan þᵗat he was come in to the town
For greet chiertee ⁊and greet affeccioun
Vn to daun Iohn he first gooth hym to pleye
Nat for to axe or borwe of hym moneye
But for to wite ⁊and seen of his weelfare
And for to tellen hym of his chaffare
As freendes doon / whan they been met I feere
Daun Iohn hym makeþ feeste ⁊and myry chieere
And he hym tolde agayn ful specially
How he hadde weel y boght ⁊and graciously
Thanked be god al hool his marchandyse
Saue þᵗat he moste in alle manere wyse
Maken a cheuyssance / as for his beste
And þanne he sholde been in Ioye ⁊and reste
¶ Daun Iohn answerede certes I am fayn
That ye in heele are comen hoom agayn
And if þᵗat I wer riche / as I haue blisse
Of twenty þousand sheeld shulde ye nat mysse
For ye so kyndely þis other day
Lente me gold ⁊and as I kan ⁊and may
I thanke bi god ⁊and by seint Iame
But nathelees I took vn to owre dame
Youre wif at hoom the same gold agayn
Vp on youre bench she woot it wel certayn
By certeyn toknes þᵗat I kan yow telle
Now by youre leue I may no lengere dwelle
Owr Abbot wole out of þis toun Anon
And in his compaignye moot I goon
Grete weel owre dame myn owne Neece swete
And farewel dere Cosyn til we meete
¶ This Marchaunt which þᵗat was ful waar ⁊and wys
Creanced haþ ⁊and payed eek in Parys
To certein lumbardes redy in hire hond
The sōmme of gold ⁊and gat of hem his bond
And hoom he gooth myrye as a Papeiay
For weel he knew he stood in swich Array
That nedes moste he wynne in þᵗat viage
A thousand Frankes a bouen al his Costage
¶ His wif ful redy mette hym atte gate
As she was wont of old vsage algate
And al þᵗat nyght in merthe they bisette
For he was riche ⁊and cleerly out of dette
Whan it was day þis Marchant gan embrace
His wif al newe / ⁊and kiste hir on hire face
And vp he goth ⁊and maketh it ful togh
Namoore quod she by god ye haue ynogh
And wantownly ageyn wᵗith hym she pleyde
Til atte laste this Marchant thus seyde
¶ Bi god quod he I am a litel wrooth
Wᵗith yow my wyf al thogh it be me looth
And wot ye why bi god as þᵗat I gesse
Þᵗat ye han maad a maneere straungenesse
Bitwixen me ⁊and my Cosyn daun Iohn
Ye shulde han warned me er I hadde goon
That he hadde yow an hundred frankes payed
By redy tokne ⁊and heeld hym yuele apayed
For þᵗat I to hym spak of cheuyssance
Me seemed so as by his contenaıı̄unce
But nathelees bi god oure heuene kyng
I thoghte nat to axe of hym no thyng
I pye the wif ne do namoore soo
Tel me alwey / er þᵗat I fro the goo
If any dettoᵘur haþ in myn absence
Ypayed the / lest thurgh thy necligence
I myghte hym axe a þyng þᵗat he hath payed
¶ This wyf was nat a fered / nor Affrayed
But boldely she / seyde ⁊and that anon
Marye I diffye / the false Monk daun Iohn
I keepe nat of hise tooknes neuer a deel
He took me certein gold this woot I weel
What yuel thedam on his Monkes snowte
For god it woot I wende wᵗith outen doute
That he hadde yeue it me by cause of yow
To doon ther wᵗith myn honour ⁊and my prow
For Cosynage ⁊and eek for beel chiere
hath had ful ofte tymes heere
se it stant in swich disioynt
I were yow shortely to þe poynt
Ye han slakkere dettours than am I
For I wole paye yow weel ⁊and redily
Fro day to day ⁊and if so be I faille
I am youre wif skore it vp on my taille
And I shal paye as soone as eủer/ree I may
For by my trouthe / I haue on myn Array
And nat in wast bisted euery dee
And for I haue bistowed it so weel
For youre honoᵘur for goddes sake I seye
As be nat wrooth but lat vs laughe ⁊and pleye
Ye shal my Ioly body han to wedde
By god I wol nat paye yow but a bedde
For gyue it me myn owne spouse deere
Turne hiderward ⁊and maketh bettre chiere
¶ This Marchaunt saugh þer was no remedye
And for to chide it nere but folye
Syn þat the thyng may nat amended bee
Now wyf he seyde ⁊and I foryeue it thee
And by þy lyf ne be namoore so large
Keepe bet thy good this yeue I the in charge
Thus endeth my tale ⁊and god vs sende
Tailynge Inogh vn to owre lyues eende
Heer is ended the Shipmannes tale .
Weel seyd by corpus domin9 quod oure hoost
Now longe moote þᵘ sayle by the coost
Thow gentil Maister / gentyl Maryneer
God yeue þe Monk a thousand last quade yeer
. A . ha . felawes / beeth waar of swich a Iape
The Monke putte in the mannes hood an Ape
And in hise wyues eek by seint Austyn
Draweth no Monkes moore in to youre In
But now passe ouer ⁊and lat vs seeke a boute
Who shal now telle first of Al this Route
A nother tale and wᵗith þat word he sayde
As curteisly as it had been a mayde
My lady Prioresse by youre leeue
So þat I wiste I sholde yow nat greeue
I wolde deemen þat ye tellen sholde
A tale next if so were þᵗat ye wolde
Now wol ye vouche it sauf my lady deere
Gladly quod she ⁊and seyde as ye shal heere
Heer folweth þe ꝓprologe of the Prioresses tale ~ .
¶ Domine dominus noster
O lord oure lord thy name how merueillous
Is in this large world ysprad quod she
For nat oonly thy laude precious
ꝐPer/Parfourned is by men of dignitee
But by þe mouth of children thy bountee
ꝐPer/Parfourned is for on the brest soukynge
Som tyme shewen they thyn heriynge
Wherfore in laude as I best kan or may
Of the ⁊and of the white lilye flour
Which þᵗat the baar and is a mayde Alway
To telle a storye I wol do my labour
Nat þᵗat I may encressen hire honour
For she hire self is honour ⁊and the roote
Of boıı̄untee next hire sone ⁊and soules boote
O mooder mayde . o mayde mooder free
O bussh vnbrent brennynge in Moyses sighte
That rauysshedest doun fro the deitee
Thurgh þyn humblesse þe goost þᵗat in the a lyghte
Of whos vertu whan he thyn herte lyghte
Conceyued was the fadres sapience
Help me to telle it in thy reuerence .
¶ Lady thy bountee / thy magnifycence
Thy vertu ⁊and thy greete humylitee
Ther may no tonge expsse in no science
For somtyme lady er men preyen thee
Thou . goost biforn of thy benygnytee
And getest vs the light of thy preyere
To gyden vs vn to thy sone so deere
My konnyng is so wayk o blisful queene
For to declare thy grete worthynesse
That I ne may the weyghte nat susteene
But as a child of twelf Monthe old or lesse
That kan vnnethe any word expresse
Right so fare I . ⁊and therfore I yow preye
Gydeth my song þt I shal of yow seye
Heer is ended the ꝓprologe of the Prioresses tale
¶ Heer bigynneth the Prioresse hire tale ~ of ~
Alma redemptoris Mater
Ther was in Asye in a greet Citee
Amonges cristen folk a Iuerye
Sustened bi a lord of that contree
For foul vsure and lucre of vileynye
Hateful to Crist ⁊and to his compaignye
And thurgh this strete men myghte ryde ⁊and wende
For it was free ⁊and open at eyther ende
A litel scole of Cristen folk there stood
Down atte ferther ende in whiche ther were
Children an heep ycomen of / cristen blood
That lerned in that scole yeer by yeere
Swych manere doctryne as men vsed there
This is to seyn to syngen ⁊and to rede
As smale childre doon in hir childhede
¶ Among thise children was a wydewes sone
A litel clergeoıı̄un seuene ȝeer of age
That day by day to scole was his wone
And eek also wher þᵗat he saugh thymage
Of Cristes mooder hadde he in vsage
As hym was taught to kneele adoun ⁊and seye
His Aue Maryie as he gooth by þe weye
Thus hath this wydwe hir litel sone ytaught
Oure blissed lady Cristes mooder deere
To worshipe ay ⁊and he for gat it nawght
For sely child wol alwey soone leere
But ay whan I remembre on this mateere
Seint Nicholas stant euere in my presence
For he so yong to Crist dide reuerence
This litel child his litel book lernynge
As he sat in the scole at his primer
He Alma redemptoris / herde synge
As Children lerned hir Antiphoneer
⁊and as he dorste he drow hym neer ⁊and neer
And herkened ay þe wordes ⁊and the noote
Til he the firste vers koude al by roote
Noght wiste he what this latyn was to seye
For he so yong ⁊and tendre was of age
But on a day his felawe gan he - preye
Texpounden hym þis song in his langage
Or tellen hym why þis song was in vsage
is pyede he hym to construen ⁊and declare
ul ofte tyme vpon his knees bare
His felawe which þᵗat eldere was than he
Answerde hym thus þis song I haue herd seye
Was maked of owre blisful lady free
Hire to salue ⁊and eek hire forto preye /
To been owre helpe ⁊and socour whan we deye
I kan namoore expounde in this matiere
I lerne song I kan but smal grāmmere /
And is this song maked in reuerence
Of Cristes mooder seyde this Innocent
Now certes I wol do my dilygence
To kune it al er Cristemasse is went
Thogh þᵗat I for my Prymer shal be shent
And shal be beten thryes in an houre
I wol it konne owre lady for to honoure /
His felawe taughte hym homward pⁱriuely
Fro day to day til he koude it by rote
And þanne he song it weel ⁊and boldely
Fro word to word accordynge wᵗith the noote
Twyes a day / it passed thurgh his throote .
To Scoleward ⁊and homward whan he wente /

l.hi: On Cristes mooder set was his entente

div.l: As I haue seyd thurgh out the Iuerye
This litel child / as he cam to ⁊and fro
Ful myrily wol synge ⁊and crye /
O. Alma redes euere mo
The swetnesse h perced so
Of Cristes mooder hire to preye

l.hi: He kan nat stynte of gynge by the weye

div.l: Owre firste foo the Serpent Sathanas
Þᵗat hath in Iues herte his waspes nest
Vp swal ⁊and seyde o hebrayk peple Allas
Is this to you a þyng þᵗat is honest
Þᵗat swich a boy / shal walken as hym lest
In youre despyt ⁊and synge of swych sentence
Which is agayns owre lawes reuerence /
¶ Fro thennes forth þe Iues han conspyred
This Innocent out of this world to chace
An homycyde ther to han they hired
Right in an aleye at a pryuee place
⁊and as þe child gan forth by for to pace
Þis cursed Iew hym hente ⁊and heeld hym faste /
And kitte his þrote / ⁊and in a pyt hym caste .
I seye / þᵗat in a warderobe þey hym threwe
Wher as thise Iues pʳgen hir entraille
O cursed folk of herodes al newe
What may youre yuel entente yow auaille
Mordre wol out certeyn it wol nat faille
⁊and namely ther as thonoᵘur of god shal sprede
The blood out cryeth on youre cursed deede
O marter sowded to virgynytee
Now maistow syngen folwyng eủer/ree in oon
Þe white lamb celestial quod she
Of which . the grete Euᵃngelist seint Iohn
In Pathmos wroot which seyth þᵗat they þᵗat goon
Biforn this lamb ⁊and synge a song al newe
Þᵗat neủer/ree flesshly wōmman they ne knewe
This poure widewe awayteþ al þᵗat nyght
After hire litel child ⁊and he cam noght
For which as soone as it was dayes light
Wᵗith face pale of drede ⁊and bisy thoght
She haþ at scole ⁊and elles where hym soght
Til fynally she gan so fer espye
That he last seyn was in the Iuerye
Wᵗith moodres pyte in hire brest enclosed
She goth as she were half out of hir mynde
To euery place where as she hath supposed
By liklyheede hire litel child to fynde
And euere on Cristes mooder meeke ⁊and kynde
She cryde ⁊and atte laste þus she wroghte
Among the cursed Iues she hym soghte
She asketh ⁊and she frayneth pitously
Of euery Iew þᵗat dwelte in thilke place
To telle hire if hir child wente oght forth by
They seyde nay but Ihu of his grace
Yaf in hir thoght In wᵗith a litel space
Þᵗat in þᵗat place after hir sone she cryde
Where he was casten in a pyt byside
O greete god þᵗat ꝑper/parfournest thy laude
By mouth of Innocentz lo heer þy myght
This gemme of chastitee this Emeraude
⁊and eek of martyrdom the Rubye bright
Ther he wᵗith throte ykoruen lith vpryght
He Alma redemptoris gan to synge
So lowde þᵗat al þe place gan to rynge
The cristen folk þᵗat thurgh þe strete wente
In coomen for to wondren vp on this þyng
And hastily they for the ꝓprouoost sente
He cam anon wᵗith outen tariyng
⁊and heryeth Crist þᵗat is of heuene kyng
And eek his mooder honour of mankynde
And after þᵗat the Iewes leet he bynde
This child wᵗith pitous lamentacioıı̄un
Vp taken was syngynge his song alway
And wᵗith honoᵘur of greet processyoıı̄un
They caryen hym vn to þe next Abbay
His mooder swownyng by his beere lay
Vnnethe myghte þe peple þᵗat was there
This newe Rachel brynge fro the beere
Wᵗith torment ⁊and wᵗith shameful deeth echon
This prouost doth thise Iewes for to sterue
Þᵗat of this mordre wiste ⁊and that anon
He nolde no swich cursednesse obserue
Yuel shal haue þᵗat yuel wol disserue
Therfore wᵗith wilde hors he dide hem drawe
And after þᵗat he heng hem by the lawe
Vp on his beere ay lith þis Innocent
Bifore the highe auteer whil þe masse laste
⁊and after þᵗat the Abbot wᵗith his Couent
Han sped hem forto buryen hym fulfaste
And whan þey hooly water on hym caste
Yet spak þis child whan spreynd was holy water
⁊and song O. Alma redemptoris mater
This Abbot which þᵗat was an hooly man
As Monkes been or ell oghten bee
Þis yonge child to coniure he bigan
⁊and seyde o. deere child I halse thee
In vertu . of the hooly trynytee
Tel me what is thy cause for to synge
Sith þᵗat þy throte is kit to my semynge
My throte is kit vn to my nekke boon
Seyde þis child ⁊and as by weye of kynde
I sholde haue dyed ye longe tyme a goon
But Ihu Crist as ye in bookes fynde
Wol þᵗat his glorye laste and be in mynde
And for the worship of his mooder deere
ynge O . Alma lowde ⁊and re
This welle of mcy Cristes mooder sweete
I loued alwey as after my konnynge
⁊and whan þᵗat I my lyf sholde for lete
To me she cam ⁊and bad me for to synge
This antheme verraily in myn deiynge
As ye han herd / ⁊and whan þᵗat I had songe
Me thoghte she leyde a greyn vp on my tonge
Wherfore I synge ⁊and synge moot certeyn
honoᵘur of that blisful mayden free
fro my tonge I taken is the greyn
er that thus seyde she to me
My litel child now wol I fecche thee
Whan þᵗat þe greyn is from thy tongue ytake
Be nat agast / I wol thee nat for sake
This hooly Monk this Abbot hym meene I
His tonge out caughte ⁊and took awey the greyn
And he yaf vp the goost ful softely
And whan this Abbot hadde this wonder seyn
Hise salte teerys trikled doun as reyn
And gruf he fil al flat vn to the grounde
And stille he lay as he had leyn ybounde
The Couent eek lay on the pauement
Wepynge ⁊and heryen Cristes mooder deere
And after that they ryse ⁊and foorth been went
And took awey þis Martir from his beere
And in a toumbe of Marbel stoones cleere
Enclosen they this litel body sweete
Ther he is now / god leeue vs for to meete
O yonge Hugh of Lyncoln slayn also
Wᵗith cursed Iewes as it is notable
For it is but a litel while I go
Preye eek for vs we synful folk vnstable
That of his mercy god so mercyable
On vs his greete mercy multiplye
For reuerence of his mooder Marye Amen .
Heer hath the Prioresse ended hir tale

l.hi:
Biholde the myrie talkyng of the
hoost to Chaucer ~~

div.l: ¶ Whan seyd was al this myracle eủer/rey man
As sobre was þᵗat wonder was to see
Til þᵗat oure hoost Iapen to bigan
And þanne at erst he looked vp on me . i . Chaucer
And seyde thus what man artow quod he ~
Thow lookest as þᵘ woldest fynde an hare
For euere vp on the ground I see the stare
Approche neer ⁊and looke vp miryly
Now war yow sires ⁊and lat þis man haue place
He in the waast is shape as weel as I .
This were a Popet in an arm tenbrace
For any wōmman smal ⁊and fayr of face
He seemeth eluyssh by his contenance
For vn to no wyght dooth he dance
Sey now som what syn oother folk han sayed
Telle vs a tale of myrthe ⁊and that anon
Hoost quod I . ne beeth nat yuele apayed
For other tale ceertes kan I noon
But of a rym I lerned longe agoon
Ye þᵗat is good quod he now shul we heere
Som deynte thyng me thynketh by his chiere

l.hi: ¶ Heere bigynneth Chaucers tale of ʆser/sire Thopas

div.l: Listeþ lordynges in good entent
⁊and I wol telle verrayement
Of myrthe ⁊and solas
Al of a knyght was fayr ⁊and gent
In bataille ⁊and in tornement
His name was ʆser/sire Thopas .
I born he was in fer Contree
In Flaundres al by yonde þe see
At ꝐPer/Paroperyng in þe place ~
His fader was a man ful free
⁊and lord he was of þᵗat Contree
As it was goddes grace
Sire Thopas wax a doghty swayn
Whyt was his face . as Payndemayn
Hise lippes reed as rose
His rode is lik skarlet in grayn
As I yow telle in good certayn
He hadde a semely nose
heer his beerd was lyk safroun
his girdel . raughte a doun
Hise shoon of cordewane
Of Brugges wer hise hosen broun
His Robe was of Siklatoun
That coste many a Iane
He koude hunte at wilde deer
And ryde on hawkyng for Ryueer
Wᵗith grey goshauk on honde
Therto he was a good Archeer
Of wrastelyng was there noon his peere
Ther any ram shal stonde
Ful many a mayde / bryght in bowr
They moorned for hym ꝑper/paramour
Whan hem were bet to sleepe
But he was chaast and no leechour
And swete as is þe brembul flour
Þᵗat bereth the rede heepe
And so it fyl vp on a day
For sothe as I yow telle may
Sire Thopas wolde owt ryde
He worthed vp on his steede bay
And in his hand a launcegay
A long swerd / by his syde
He prikeþ thurgh a fayr Forest
There Inne is many a wilde beest
Ye bothe bukkes ⁊and hare
And as he priketh North ⁊and Eest
I telle it yow hym hadde almeest
Bityd a sory caare
There spryngen herbes greete ⁊and smale
The Lycorys and Cetewale
And many a Clowe Gilofre
And Notemuge to putte in Ale
